participants.participant: Elena Doom, Vice President, Investor Relations
David M. Cote, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
David J. Anderson, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer

plist.p: Good day everyone. Welcome to the Honeywell fourth quarter and full year 2009 conference call. Today's call is being recorded.
At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to Elena Doom, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, ma'am.

Hi, thank you, Cecilia. Good morning and welcome to our fourth quarter and full-year 2009 earnings conference call. Here with me today are Chairman and CEO Dave Cote and Senior Vice President and CFO Dave Anderson. This call and webcast including any non-GAAP reconciliation are available on our website at www.honeywell.com/investor.

Note that elements of this presentation contain forward-looking statements that are based on our best view of the world and of our businesses as we see them today. Those elements can change and we would ask that you interpret them in that light.

This morning we will review our financial results for the fourth quarter and the full year 2009 as well as our expectations for the first quarter of 2010. And of course we'll allow time for your questions.
With that I'll turn the call over to Dave Cote.

Thanks, Elena, good morning everyone. I'm pleased to report a strong finish to 2009 with another quarter of good results despite a continued tough economic environment. And it closes out an interesting year, marked by the worst recession in many years.

Our results in 2009 reinforced the significance of our longstanding company strategy: our focus on having great positions in good industries; the continued investments we have made in exciting new products, emerging region expansion, and our key process improvement levers; our five initiatives; the talent and depth of our management team; and the power of One Honeywell.

Dave will take us through the details of the quarter in a moment, but let me say I am extremely proud of this Honeywell team delivering on the financial commitments we set earlier in the year despite worsening and unprecedented economic headwinds. We proved we were a company that could be trusted to perform in both the good times and the bad.

With that, let's look at the quarter. We executed well with sales of 8.1 billion. We were able to generate earnings per share of $0.91 including covering an additional 34 million or $0.03 in earnings of repositioning actions. While the top line environment continued to be challenging, we were able to deliver these results because of the strong growth initiatives and aggressive cost actions we put in place throughout Honeywell as evidenced by our ability to preserve and grow margins in this environment.
Segment margins were 15.3% in the quarter, up 200 basis points from prior year. And we finished the year at 13.3%, flat on almost $6 billion less in sales.

In the quarter, we generated over 1 billion of free cash flow, taking free cash flow for the year over $3.3 billion, exceeding both our expectations and prior year, which really reinforces the quality of our earnings.

Our key initiatives continue to gain traction in our businesses and functions every day, and we have a lot more room for even further improvement. We continue to drive productivity across the organization and remain focused on flawlessly executing or repositioning projects we've already initiated.

The focus on fixed costs remains a priority for us. For example, our focus on reducing our indirect spend is working. It saved us more than 20% of spend in 2009. Actions like plant shutdowns and furloughs were taken where appropriate and saved approximately $200 million this year while also maintaining our industrial base. These are all difficult actions, but our team executed well and responded quickly to changing market conditions.

We accomplished these results while continuing our seed planting for the future, where we've continued to invest even in these turbulent times; seed planting investments in strategic, innovative platforms like smart controls that tie into the revamped electrical grid. We are well positioned to support the development of the smart grid through our industry leading building and residential controls, energy efficiency solutions, and wireless technologies, all of which are key components to a successful smart grid.

These solutions are not only enhancing Honeywell's position in this very attractive segment, but the opportunity for energy efficiency is significant because residential and commercial buildings consume 80% of the electricity in the United States. There are energy efficiency opportunities in each of our businesses. If aggressively applied today, Honeywell products and services could reduce energy consumption by 15 to 20%.

Our investments focused in emerging regions are also really paying off, with sales growth in the quarter offsetting some of the declines we saw in developed regions. In the quarter, Specialty Materials opened up a new technology center in Gurgaon, India, to expand their global research capabilities in refining, petrochemical, and other technologies in order to better serve the region. Investing approximately $34 million, the center will primarily house pilot plants for developing and demonstrating UOP process technologies, strengthening our commercialization capabilities globally, but especially in Asia where it will complement our existing research center in Shanghai. The challenge for us as well as the opportunity is to move at an even faster pace in these regions.

Also, we continue to invest in our big process initiatives as well as other seed planting across the organization such as the Honeywell Operating System, Velocity Product Development, and Functional Transformation, which have been huge enablers for growth and cost savings this year. With 80% of our manufacturing cost base now within HOS deployment and many of them in Phase 4 or better, where we start seeing transformational results, we are seeing real momentum across the organization.

Velocity Product Development or VPD continues to be a significant driver and is yielding very real benefits for us today in businesses like ECC [Environmental Combustion and Controls], where we continue to win market share with new products; and in Aerospace, where our development costs and cycle times have been materially reduced, thus further increasing our competitive advantage on future platforms.

Functional Transformation saved the company over $200 million this year while service quality improves. We continue to drive additional productivity through shared SAP infrastructure and applications as we near almost 60% completion of our company-wide ERP rollout.

Finally, I just spent two days with our top 300 leaders, where we concentrated almost exclusively on preparing ourselves for the pending recovery. While it is difficult to predict when and what it will look like, we are as usual planning conservatively in 2010 with modest organic sales growth, and we will continue to be judicious about maintaining good cost controls.

So while we should all be cautious about the year ahead of us, particularly the first half, I feel good about the investments we have been making in our businesses for the past eight years to prepare us for an even better recovery. HOS, FT, ERP, Velocity Product Development, emerging region presence, and acquisitions are all seeds that we have planted to help improve our growth, productivity, and cash flow. We have the right leadership team in place to deliver even better results in the recovery. And I have asked all of our business leaders to be prepared for a rapid recovery. We believe that because we maintained our industrial base, we are prepared internally. We will be focusing even more attention on the preparedness of our supply base.

So in summary, a strong finish to difficult year, decisively demonstrating Honeywell is a very different company, able to execute well operationally, deliver on our financial commitments, and continue to invest in the future even in a tough economic environment.
So with that, let me turn it over to Dave.

Thanks, Dave, good morning everybody; thanks for joining us. Please turn to slide four entitled Financial Summary. And as you can see and as Dave said, we posted earnings results that were in line with the guidance we provided you in October. Reported sales for the quarter were down 7%, in line with expectations, or down 12% organically. That is the excluding the impact of both foreign exchange as well as acquisitions net of divestitures.

Now despite the drop in sales, segment profit in the quarter increased 6% over the prior year, with segment margins up a full 200 basis points to 15.3%. And we saw further good margin performance from ACS [Automation and Control Solutions], which was up 130 basis in the quarter, and impressive year-over-year gains in both Specialty Materials and Transportation Systems. These gains in margin points were partially offset by the expected weakness at Aero, which was down 50 basis points on continued weakness in the commercial aftermarket.

Net income in the quarter declined 1%. EPS declined 6%. As you'll recall, we reviewed the effective tax rate assumptions with you last quarter, and we indicated we'd have a higher ETR in the fourth quarter, about 30%. That's where we came in, and that compares to last quarter's lower tax rate; that is the third quarter lower tax rate of 22%.

We also had higher pension and OPEB [Other Post-Employment Benefit] expense, 22 million in the quarter. And relevant to our guidance and expectations, we had higher asbestos, about 24 million, and higher repositioning of about 26 million. Those expenses were offset by a gain on an asset sale; so again relative to our expectation, these items mostly offset and in line with guidance.

Free cash flow, as Dave said, particularly strong in the quarter, over $1 billion, approximately flat with the prior year, a very high quality story that equates to a 154% conversion to net income in the quarter, again reinforcing the core processes we have in place around the organization to drive cash and again reinforcing the quality of the earnings.

On slide five, looking at the full year now, 2009 results, you see in line with our guidance that we gave you. Reported sales were down 15% for the year or around $5.7 billion less compared to 2008, obviously reflecting the tough economic environment in '09. And we had of course declines in all of the four business units. However, what's impressive is our ability to take out approximately $5 billion of costs, holding segment margins flat to the 2008 levels at 13.3%.

Each of the businesses responded exceptionally well to the progressively weakening end markets that we experienced over the course of 2009, staying on top of these market shifts, aggressively reducing costs, while also maintaining our industrial base and continuing to invest for the future. Both ACS and SM actually saw margin rate improvement on a year-over-year basis.

Net income for the full year 2009 was down 23%, with higher pension expenses, including 171 million of net also that results – those results reflect 171 million of net funded repositioning actions in the year. And all of this funding came through operational performance and gains which will provide even greater support of course for 2010 and 2011.
EPS for the year was down 24% to our targeted 2.85 for the year. We generated, as Dave said, a record $3.3 billion in free cash flow or 155% of net income, again another high quality year.

Now before I take you through the individual segments, I just want to remind you that in 2009, we also had a number of policy related actions that allowed us to reduce labor costs in these times while still being able to preserve our industrial base. These actions included furloughs, reduced work schedules, merit lower incentive compensation. All of these favorably impacted every margin performance in the year depending on the shape of their end-market conditions for '09.

Now for planning purposes, you'll recall from our December 16 guidance, we've built most of these costs back into 2010 as we believe they're essential to maintain the organization's momentum to achieve our long-term growth strategy, and also consistent with the outlook of the economic assumptions and market assumptions that we've used for our 2010 guidance. Now while this represents an approximately $500 million headwind; that is those costs coming back in in '10 or approximately 160 basis points of margin, we look to offset most or all that headwind, and you recall that from our December 16 walk, EPS walk, with incremental repositioning benefits as well as lower year-over-year repositioning expense in '10, a total of approximately $400 million.

So with background on the full year for 2009, let's go through each of the segments starting with slide number six, Aerospace. Aero sales in the quarter were down 18% with segment profit down 20%; margins down 60 basis points, as I said, as lower volumes were partially offset by productivity improvements driven by cost savings initiatives and also the benefits from prior repositioning actions. Total commercial sales, that is the sum of the ATR, the Air Transport business, and BGA, the Business and General Aviation business, were down 29% in the quarter, with declines across both OE and aftermarket.

Commercial OE sales were down 39%, with Air Transport and Regional sales up 12% on a reported basis. However, when you take into account the impact of the fourth quarter 2008 Boeing strike, sales would have been down 15% due to platform mix at Airbus and the timing of shipments to regional jet customers. Business Jet OE sales were down 76% as a result of the significant customer reschedules and cancellations of deliveries that occurred in '09. And that number, as dramatic as it is, is consistent with our guidance and the expectation for the quarter.

Commercial aftermarket sales were down 21% in total. Although flight activity is improving with consecutive positive flight-hour growth, we're still seeing declines year over year in the ATR business. In fact, the aftermarket sales in ATR were down 21% in the quarter as we continue to see airlines aggressively manage their inventories, defer maintenance events, and also cannibalize parked aircraft for spares. And given the continuation of airline destocking coupled with the rising number of parked aircraft, lower initial provisioning of spares when new planes are delivered, the combination of these, we anticipate the trend to continue in the first half of '10 with only slight improvement in the second half. Again, that's a theme that's consistent with what we talked to you about in December.

B&GA aftermarket sales were down 23%. It's a slight improvement over the third quarter, in line with the positive trend sequentially we're seeing in improving business jet utilization rates as well as our measurement of TFE or turbo fan engines hours and maintenance, reflecting stability at these new lower levels.

For Defense and Space in Aero, sales were flat for the year, with higher sales of government services and original equipment for military platforms partially offset by lower sales of commercial helicopter systems. Sales were down for D&S 4% in the quarter, mainly driven by the expected ramp down of tank utilization as the focus shifts obviously to Afghanistan, negatively impacting sales on the TIGER [Total InteGrated Engine Revitalization] program.

In addition, we saw some negative mix associated with T55 engines on the Chinook helicopter and continued pressure on missile guidance systems, partially offset by growth in government services. On the other hand, the government services business was up 8% per year. It continues to provide logistics support services to military bases throughout the world and is very well positioned as we go forward. Overall for D&S, we continue to expect stable to moderate growth for that segment of Aero in 2010.

So in summary, continued tough market conditions in the Commercial Aerospace business, particularly in business jet OE, where we'll continue to see difficult comps in the first half of '10 and also in large air transport aftermarket.

So with that background on Aero, let's now turn to slide seven, ACS. Automation and Control Solutions for the year, down 4% in 2009; for the quarter, down 12% organic excluding 5% positive currency and 3% acquisition, with the biggest declines in the Americas and Europe partially offset by the growth in emerging regions. And as Dave said, we saw good growth and nice performance in emerging regions in the fourth quarter and as we exited the year.

Foreign exchange was a positive contributor for the first time this year for ACS segment margins; were also obviously a good story in the quarter, up an impressive 130 basis points to 14.7%, reflecting the impact of cost controls as well as the introduction of new products and the continued strong performance of ACS in its respective markets.

While our products businesses were down 6% organically in the quarter, there are pockets of stabilization emerging, namely in the industrial channel, supported by increases in manufacturer production and the impact favorably of increased safety regulations. Sensing & Control, Scanning & Mobility both saw good sequential growth building backlog and in winning new projects; for example, like the UPS order that you saw released, an order to deploy nearly 100,000 mobile computers over the next few years, replacing their entire worldwide fleet with Honeywell products.

Our Life Safety and Environmental & Combustion Controls, both down in the quarter, are being impacted by softness in commercial construction, partially offset by new products focused on energy efficiency, home control, and wireless fire and gas detection devices. Further we're also seeing a rapid rebound, as I mentioned, in China product. Sales were up 18% organically in the quarter.

Our Solutions business in ACS, while down 8% organically, continued to hold up well. Demand for energy efficiency as well as the integration of climate, fire, and security controls for critical infrastructure continues to drive growth within Building Solutions. On the Process Solutions side, service revenues continue to represent a solid base, offsetting declines that we're seeing related to spending delays in OpEx and CapEx, primarily by US and European refiners.

Orders in the fourth quarter in Solutions were flat organically driven by a number of large energy efficiency wins in the quarter offset by order delays in Process Solutions, again particularly with US refiners. In the quarter, Building Solutions was awarded a 79 million renewable energy and building retrofit program with Eastern Illinois University. In 2009, energy orders for HBS totaled over $650 million, reflecting a 45% increase over the prior year, and again reflects the strength of our position with government and infrastructure projects both in the US and around the world.
Our service bank increased in both Buildings and Process Solutions as we continue to benefit from our installed base of over 5 million buildings and 10,000 industrial sites.

ACS segment profit, up 5% in the fourth quarter versus last year; we saw an impressive 130 basis point increase in the margin to 14.7%, again largely driven by productivity actions, including a reduction in indirect spending and the favorable impact of prior period repositioning. It was a great effort by ACS to continue to execute also in the quarter and for the full year on new product introductions, acquisition integrations, all of which contributed to their ability to hold segment profit dollars essentially flat on a 10% reduction in sales for the full year.

Now let's turn to Transportation Systems, slide number eight. TS sales were up 13%, including a favorable 9% foreign currency benefit in the quarter. Excluding the impact of foreign exchange, sales were up 4%, driven by volume increases, primarily at Turbo.

Now at Turbo, we saw the rate of change dramatically improve from down 30% in the third quarter to up 22% in the fourth quarter, with revenue up 18% sequentially – Dave, that snapback that you're talking about, reflecting share gains on a number of new platforms being launched in the fourth quarter, an increase of approximately 170,000 units for Turbo. We're also seeing positive macro trends with an increase in European light vehicle production, a modest rebound in diesel penetration, as well as the sharp recovery in commercial vehicle production in Asia.

Honeywell of course is going to continue to benefit from our win rates on attractive new turbo gas and diesel platforms in '10. A good example of that is the recent launch of the Ford EcoBoost platforms for both the 3.5-liter as well as the upcoming 6.7-liter engines. In addition to the new platform wins, we've had approximately $2 billion of new platform wins in 2009. And the favorable macro trends around energy efficiency and lower emissions give us confidence in the outlook for 2010 and of course for the long-term prospects for this business.

CPG [Consumer Products Group] within TS, sales were down 2% recorded but up slightly, about 3%, if you excluded the pass-through impact of lower raw material pricing; that is ethylene glycol. As you know, EG is an influence obviously on the top line there of CPG's performance.

We continue to see a much improved business performance with CPG with double-digit margins being delivered in 2009. Segment profit for TS was up 66 million in the quarter, taking segment margins to 7.4%, the high contribution margin obviously associated with the Turbo business being a key driver, as well as the progress that the TS team has made on productivity and cost actions, with fixed costs down approximately 15% in the fourth quarter.

For the full year, sales for Transportation Systems were 3.4 billion, down 27%. Segment margins were 4.6%, down 420 basis points from prior year. But obviously, that uptick in the fourth quarter is a good portender of things to come in TS.

Specialty Materials, let's go to slide number nine. As you can see for the quarter, Specialty Materials grew segment profit 56% on a 5% decline in sales, expanding margins by 670 basis points to a record 17%. It's a credit to the work that the SM team has continued to do to aggressively manage costs, but also investment in innovation and their renewed sales focus during the downturn.

Now as expected, UOP sales were down in the quarter. They were actually down 13% due to continued deferrals of long-cycle projects due to weakness in both CapEx spending in refining as well as the petrochemical end market. However, the backlog at UOP is stable. Orders are improving, and we're expecting modest growth, as you recall from our guidance, which continues for 2010.

Catalyst sales, which were up 1% in the quarter, benefit from the timing of catalyst reloads. And as always, there will always be variability quarter to quarter in catalyst shipments and the mix of licensing revenues in UOP, which again will always be difficult to predict, so our continued focus will always be on the full-year guidance for this business.

Resins and chemicals were up 18% in the quarter, benefiting from improved business conditions, including demand for nylon in Asia, which more than offset the impact of lower raw material price costs on pricing. In addition, we're seeing sequential and year-over-year improvement in our electronic materials business, with many of our customers signaling improved conditions and inventory restocking actually occurring in that segment.

Fluorine products, while down in the quarter, we're starting to see end markets stabilize. In addition to the significant operational improvement we're seeing in that business over the last two years, we've continued to invest in a number of new environmentally friendly technologies that we'll begin to commercialize over the next year and a half.

Now as I mentioned earlier, segment profit for SM was up 175 million – up 275 million in the quarter. Margins were up 670 basis points to 17% on terrific cost controls, including an 11% reduction in indirect spend in SM and also lower raw material costs, despite lower volumes and the continued investments that SM makes for growth, and again a very good quarter.

Now let's turn to slide 10, which gives us an update on our guidance for 2009. Now on the top of slide 10, we summarized the guidance that we shared with you last month. And at the bottom of the slide 10, we've outlined a few of the positive variances on the right and some of the less encouraging developments or variances on the left. These are just simply directional updates since our December 16 call. Overall, we still expect to be in the range of our full-year guidance that we communicated last month.

So let me take you through some of the specifics, starting at the bottom of the page with pension. As you recall from the December call, our base case pension expense assumptions were for 12/31/09 plan returns and discount rate of 20% and 5.5% respectively, yielding an expense for 2010 of $850 million. Actual returns came in at roughly 20%. However, we saw interest rates or discount rates improve slightly to 5.75%. This results in revised pension guidance for 2010 of approximately 820 million, which includes an incremental 20 million of foreign plan expense that we factored in for 2010.

Working our way down the remaining positive items on the right, the Turbo and ACS businesses continue to perform well as evidenced by their impressive margin improvement in the fourth quarter. New program launches, energy efficiency products and solutions, emerging market expansion, all of those continue to be positive contributors to both of these businesses and we're increasingly confident in their full-year outlook. We don't have the same better visibility at this time on the NARCO 524g Trust. Given this uncertainty, we could see cash funding requirements slip into 2011, therefore having a positive impact on free cash flow for the year.

On the left hand side, consistent with the tough performance we saw in air transport and regional, we anticipate that softness to continue through the first half of the year. Further given the risk of continued program delays in defense, some things could shift to the right. Therefore, we still expect a stable to modest D&S growth in 2010. And lastly, we're continuing to monitor working capital performance in light of the very strong contribution that we saw from working capital in the quarter.

So there are some individual puts and takes, really more directional in nature at this time, and the overall assumptions and the numbers that we are continuing to provide as guidance are consistent with what we've communicated on December 16.

Now before I take you through the first quarter outlook, I'd like to just take a moment to review our repositionings and benefit assumptions, just to again remind you of those. That's slide number 11. What we've shown you here is the repositioning for 2008 through 2010 in terms of total repositioning actions. Since '08, we funded over 600 million of gross repositionings together with our planning assumption of approximately 50 million of repositioning actions in '10. We're still anticipating significant incremental benefits in 2010. The actions were funded through again operational performance and gains in the year, which allowed us to fund census reductions of approximately 12,000. That said, emerging regions census is flat, so most of those reductions came out of our developed markets.

As a reminder, these projects create a permanent reduction for us. And stated another way, the costs are out. They're not coming back, and the average payback for this repositioning is about a year and half, 1.5 years. Therefore, we're anticipating over 300 million of incremental savings associated with these actions.

So with that background in repositioning, let's go to slide 12 and do a first quarter preview. We're planning for total sales in the first quarter to be in the range of 7.2 to 7.6 billion, flat to down slightly from prior year on an organic growth decline of approximately 2%. And we expect EPS to be in the range of $0.35 to $0.40. Excluding pension, EPS is forecast to be approximately flat to prior year, to the first quarter 2009.

Now given the progressively worsening conditions we saw early in '09, we're expecting comparisons in the first half of '10 to continue to be challenging year over year. While we're seeing improvements in the overall rate of revenue decline and sequential stabilization, the air transport regional aftermarket, Business and General Aviation OE, and the long-cycle commercial construction in UOP will face continued year-over-year headwinds in the first half.

On the other hand, turbochargers, ACS industrial products, and BGA aftermarket are all positioned to grow off their low 2009 base. In addition, we'll see incremental benefits from the repositioning actions that we funded in '08 in '09. Those will layer in throughout the year. These benefits in combination with easier second half year-over-year comps and stable end markets should drive a stronger half for Honeywell.

So when you look at the EPS guidance for the first quarter of $0.35 to $0.40, we're on track to achieve about the same linearity that we saw last year. That is approximately a 40:60 split first half versus second half.

We anticipate Aerospace sales to be in the range of 2.3 to 2.5 billion, down 10 to 13%, with continued softness in commercial Aerospace. Sales to air transport OE and BGA OE customers will continue to be down, reflecting further sharp year-over-year declines at business jet due to reduced delivery schedules, although the level of spend on our business troughed in the fourth quarter. The airlines' aftermarket we expect, as we've talked about, will continue to be weak. However, we anticipate current run rate levels to hold. And finally for Aero, we expect continued stability in Defense & Space.

For ACS, we expect sales in the first quarter to be in the range 3 to 3.1 billion, approximately flat to prior year, driven by the favorable impact of foreign exchange, the RMG acquisition, and growth in both emerging regions and energy efficiency in both Products and Building Solutions offset by some continued softness in commercial construction end markets and the deferrals of long-cycle projects due to the weakness in the refining segment of Process Solutions.

At TS, sales in the quarter are estimated to be in the range of 0.8 to 0.9 billion, up double digits, driven by new launches in Turbo and the favorable impact of foreign exchange. And we expect CPG's strong operational performance to continue in addition to similar benefits from productivity actions that we saw in 2009 across Transportation Systems.

And finally at SM, for the quarter we anticipate sales in the range 1.0 to 1.1 billion, up slightly due to some inventory restocking in selected markets, commercialization of new products, and channel recovery in key niche segments, namely nylon and electronics, partially offset by lower catalyst shipments in UOP.
So in summary, we are seeing some signs of improvement with stabilization across a number of our businesses and in line with our cautious outlook for the first quarter.

So now let's summarize before turning back to Q&A. So as we've said and as Dave stated in his comments, opening comments, we clearly finished – clearly, clearly very, very pleased with the finish for 2009. Our performance underscores the organization's ability to respond to unprecedented economic headwinds and yet deliver on the financial commitments we set earlier in the year. We were able to reduce costs, hold margins, while sustaining growth investments. It reinforced that we're a very different company today and one that is well positioned as the economy recovers.

And as usual, we employ reasonable judgment in our planning assumptions. Those of you who are familiar with it know that we take a focused top-down macro view of each of our end markets in our businesses and couple that with a detailed bottom-up business review in the course of our planning process. While we're certainly not immune to changes in the economy, we've certainly proved our resilience. We'll use that ability to weather the varying external conditions, by remaining conservative in our top line assumptions, while also preparing for economic recovery.

Aerospace today of course is lean, customer focused, and has the stability of $5 billion plus in Defense business. ACS has attractive new products leveraged to the megatrends of energy efficiency and safety and security. Transportation is already seeing the positive impact of the end of channel destocking as well as the share gains we have experienced winning a significant number of new platforms from the last few years. And lastly, Specialty Materials is a top performer, much better positioned today to protect and grow its bottom line in various economic cycles.
We have several levers in place that maintain our flexibility should economic conditions prove to be more positive or negative. Taking all of this into account, we're confident in our 2010 guidance.

Lastly, we're looking forward to our upcoming annual Investor Conference in New York City, which will be held on Monday, February 22. You're going to hear more from Dave about how we're a different, stronger company, with great positions in good industries, executing well on our five initiatives, and the strength of One Honeywell culture, our playbook for long-term value creation. And we intend to showcase our key growth drivers including our robust technology pipeline as well as expansion and growth in exciting and emerging markets. We'll demonstrate how the results of these investments are showing up in technology wins, in share gain, in profitable growth, and fundamentally that our strategy is working and will continue to deliver over the long term.
So with that, Elena, let's turn it over to you for Q&A.
Cecilia, we'll take our first question.
We'll go first to Nigel Coe of Deutsche Bank.
Thanks, good morning.
Hi, Nigel.

So to date, how do we interpret the 1Q guidance? If I look at the past, you've typically done 20% of your earnings in the first quarter. I think the midpoint suggests 16% this time. Does it mean that you're factoring in a significant ramp up in the second half of the year and therefore a bit more risk in the second half?

I wouldn't interpret it that way, Nigel. I think the quarter as we look at it in terms of the layout for the full year is very consistent with the pattern of both recovery that we're seeing in certain businesses as well as, as I mentioned earlier, the continued headwinds that we have in some of our other businesses, so it's very, very much consistent with that.

The other thing that really gives us confidence is the execution, the performance that we delivered in 2009 and the – if you look at the run rate, if you look sequentially in terms of the run rate performance of our businesses and our cost structure, it really gives us I think additional confidence in 2010. I think the distribution in terms of that 40:60 is really – again, it's just a phenomenon related to what we experienced in '09, which is playing out again this year, which is we we'll see differences between our short-cycle and our later-cycle businesses that will influence that distribution.
From a percent-to-year basis too, I think it's right in line.
It's right in line, yes, very much, thank you. Another good point Dave just made is if you look at the EPS as a percent of the full year, it's very, very much in line, yes.

Okay. And it seems to me – as Dave said in his opening remarks, it seems that the ramp up is not a question of if but when. Is it fair to say that since the December call that you may be more positive and you have a bit more confidence in your 2010 plan?

I would say – excuse me, going into any year, we have a lot of confidence in our plan, and over the last eight years it worked seven times. Last year was the only time when we had confidence in our plan and got surprised by how bad things were. I would say I don't expect this year to be a reprise of that.

I think we understand what's going on now, and I think we understand what recovery could look like, and there are a lot of possibilities there. But we're really going to make sure that we are prepared if things don't recover in a V shape. But we're also working to make sure we're prepared if it is a V shape because it's tough to know. You can't predict these things. I tend to believe generally steep-in/steep-out, slow-in/slow-out. I don't think that's an unreasonable way to look at it. So we have some businesses that could snap back pretty quickly, and our biggest concern is making sure our supply base is prepared, and that's where we're putting a lot of our attention.

So overall, I say I'd expect that on a macro basis that we're planning thoughtfully and conservatively like we usually do, and I expect this year will look more like the other seven than it did last year.

One quick follow-on on Space and Defense. Space and Defense is always back-end loaded. It sounds like from Dave Anderson's remarks that it could be more so this year. Should we be preparing for a decline in the first half?
You're talking about Defense & Space, Nigel?
Yes.

I think with Defense & Space, what we saw obviously was a little bit of softness at the year end; but frankly from an overall standpoint, not too much of a surprise. We think we take a prudent approach to D&S for 2010 with our, if you will, stable to slightly up expectation. We would expect the first half to be flat to maybe up slightly to the prior year; so really when you look at the two halves and the full-year guidance, there really isn't too much difference.
Okay.
There's that fourth quarter appropriations issue too.

Yes, you also have eight points out too. There's the appropriations process challenge for all the industry in the fourth quarter of 2010. So that impacted us as well, and that will continue to roll through and get sorted out over the course of 2010. But I think flat to up slightly in the first half and flat to up slightly for the full year for Defense & Space is a pretty good way to look at it.
Okay, thanks for the color.
You're welcome.
We'll take our next question from John Inch of Merrill Lynch.
Hello, can you hear me?
Yes, hi, John.
Hi John.

Hi guys, sorry. Just to follow on without beating a dead horse here, the 40:60 split implies, I think if you do $0.37 – $0.38 in the first quarter, it would imply a 45% ramp to get to $0.54 – $0.55 for the second quarter to get to the midpoint of your yearly guide. So my question actually is, are you planning to front load a bunch of restructuring charges this year, and if you could just remind us what restructuring actions you are planning and how you see those playing out over the course of 2010?
First of all, I don't think the ramp that you imply is actually required to get to the 40:60. So John, we can compare those numbers and math offline.

But in terms of repositioning, the repositioning guidance you'll recall is in the range of about $50 million for 2010. Think of that as down 100 to $120 million from 2009's actual net repositioning. So that will be part of – in terms of our math when you do walk, that's part of the positive contribution from repositioning in addition to the $300 million of incremental benefits, OI benefit, operating income benefits, some actions that we took in '08 and '09...
That we still have to execute.

...that we're still executing on. We've got a very, very full plate, as Dave's comment would suggest. So in addition to those benefits, also on a year-over-year basis the operating income benefits assumed in our guidance a lower spend in '10 compared to '09.

Okay, if you take 2.30 as your guide for the year, 40% of that is $0.92. So if you subtract $0.375 from $0.92, that leaves you $0.55 for Q2, which is a 45% ramp. Anyway, I want ask you on your cash flow, why was your payables such a large number, and maybe just a little color around the payables and the cash and obviously if you expect that to be sustained?

We saw real lumpiness in payables over the course of the year, and frankly it's consistent with what we saw also towards the end of 2008, John. With the variability in the decline in revenues and our inventory reductions as well as the reduction in indirect spend and also CapEx, all of those contributed in the first part of the year to a significant decline in payables. And therefore payables is actually a use of cash in the beginning of the year. And what we saw is normalization patterns in terms of inventory levels, again indirect spend stabilizing at obviously a much reduced level, as well as CapEx, all of which contributed interestingly enough to a rebound of payables in the fourth quarter. So that variability or lumpiness in payables is something that's really a reflection of the dynamics of the trend, if you will, in the economic environment back to Honeywell specifics in terms of operational actions that we took.

Now there could be some influence or impact of that into the first quarter and the first half of 2010, thus the reference that we made when I went through the update on the guidance slide. I think it was slide number 10. When I went through the reference for the 2010 cash flow, what I referenced was the 2009 working capital performance at year end on one side, if you will, a headwind in terms of an influencer, and on the right side the uncertainty in terms of the timing of funding the NARCO 524(g) trust on the other side. So I think we're balanced in terms of the full year when we look at our 2.4 to 2.7 billion free cash flow guidance for '10, but obviously the first part of year will be influenced by any overhang of that very positive delivery of working capital in the fourth quarter.
John?
Yes?

Just in case your question was just a tangential way of asking if we made our cash flow by withholding payments to suppliers at the end of the year, the answer is no. That's one of the things that we steadfastly prohibit across the company is we work with our suppliers. We get the terms that we agree to. We pay on the same schedule every month. So the answer is no and we're almost religious about making sure we don't deviate from that.
No, that wasn't my angle. I was more interested in does this somehow reverse and create a headwind near term.
Okay, just in case.

I know, I hear you. Just lastly, did you guys change your flight hour assumptions for the year? And just perhaps remind us how you see still flight hours playing out and how that dovetails into your aftermarket business.
We still see flight hours positive. In fact, we've seen positive trends in air transport global flight hours for the last three to four months, John. We're actually seeing...
And cargo.

...and also as Dave said, a very good point also, a ramp up in cargo. So think of the full-year assumption as somewhere in the 2.5 to 3.5 up, growth in global flying hours. But again what we've got is the disconnect between utilization measured in flight hours, which historically has been a very good indicator of our aftermarket business, our commercial ATR aftermarket business. We've got a disconnect now due to the "destocking" phenomenon, driven by deferred maintenance, driven by cannibalization of spares, and also driven by obviously the initial provisioning of the reduction in spares purchases as initial provisioning on new equipment on OE orders, which we include that initial provisioning as part of our aftermarket calculation in terms of how we capture aftermarket.

It's one of the areas that concerns me the most on a snap-back because there -- the reduction in inventory, the cannibalization of planes has to have been significant, and that's I think the area that concerns me the most.
And you're not assuming any kind of restock by the airlines to any degree this year, are you as part of your guide?
No, not even close.
So that's theoretically some upside there -- that starts. Okay, thanks very much.
You're welcome.
We'll take our next question from Scott Davis of Morgan Stanley.
Hi, good morning guys.
Hey, Scott.

I'm a little baffled too with the 1Q guidance. Just to support John and Nigel, their math is correct. You haven't had a quarter where you've put 16% of the net full-year number up ever as far as we have in our models. Is there something that you're seeing in January numbers that lead you to be this conservative? We're already a third through the quarter and that's a pretty abysmal guidance number.

Yes, I think part of the confusion is that we're talking about ex-pension when we think about that distribution of those numbers. So when we look at the numbers on an ex-pension basis, on a percent change, you just don't get to that kind of ramp up on a quarterly basis. So that's part of the challenge. It's more in the neighborhood of about 17 to 18% change when you look at it on that basis.

Okay. But to answer my question, are you seeing anything in January that would lead you to be this conservative? Look, I'm not going to fault you for being conservative. There is a lot of uncertainty out in the world right now. But we are a third into the quarter; and with January I can understand the guide. If you haven't, then it gets to be pretty challenging to...
No, we haven't. No, no. I think everything looks consistent, Scott, with the linearity that we developed earlier, and the guidance is consistent with that.
Okay.

We think the linearity actually makes a lot of sense ex-pension. So I guess maybe it's something that you guys will have to look at offline together, but we actually think it's quite supportive of what we've said.
Yes, I'm going to respectfully disagree, but that's okay.
That's why I'm hopeful you guys actually talk about this before you start writing away, Scotty.
Got it, and that's why I say respectfully.
That would be a first.
Anyway, can you guys talk about your book-to-bill? As you exited the year, is there some overall book-to-bill that you think about that you calculate or by segment?

I think the best way to look at that, Scott, is in the aggregate in terms of the backlog for our long-cycle businesses. And if you look at the backlog at 12/31/08 compared to the backlog at 12/31/09, the numbers are essentially the same. It's in the $11 billion range, down a little bit, I think down maybe around 2% 2009 year end compared to 2008.

Now the mix is a lot different, which you would expect. You've got business jet OE way down obviously, but you've got the buildup as we talked about earlier in Building Solutions, in energy efficiency, and a number of other areas within the business. So overall, the backlog, when you use backlog as an indicator of health for total Honeywell, how we're performing in this environment, I'd say that that's a positive indicator as we go into 2010.
Okay, so does that mean book-to-bill greater than one as we enter 2010? Is that what you're saying, Dave?

It varies so much by business, and book-to-bill is I think a difficult indicator, Scott, just because of the timing of the difference between when we book orders and when we actually bill across our various businesses. So I tend to look more at the aggregate backlog as an overall indicator.
Okay.
When you look to book-to-bill, you have to get down to very specific businesses.
Right, I get it. Okay, all right, guys. Thank you.
You're welcome.
We'll go next to Shannon O'Callaghan of Barclays Capital.
Good morning guys.
Good morning, Shannon.
Hey. Shannon.

All right, I didn't want to have to ask a pension question, but you made me from all this discussion. So just to clarify on pension, is the pension expense in 2010, does it – last year you had a curtailment gain and different things. Is it lumpy through '10 or is it linear? And then just also what's your current thinking on '11? Obviously there is a lot of variables.
So, the question is – Shannon, your question is pension lumpy through 2010?
Yes.

It's basically linear through the year. The one thing that always occurs with pension is the true-up of the estimates on our foreign plans, so that will influence it. Also anything that we may do in terms of restructuring actions where there is a defined benefit plan impact that may recognize – we may have to recognize, if you will, a curtailment or, if you will, a wind-up or a partial wind-up in an individual quarter. So you can get some lumpiness associated with true-up of foreign plan expense, and you can get some lumpiness when you think about the potential restructuring impacts. But other than that, really think about it as linear.
So it's not higher in 1Q?
No.
Okay, and then just based on where things shook out at the end of 2010, just thinking on '11 and '12, just big picture?
Tell me again, I'm sorry?
On '11 and '12, obviously discount rate swing has a big factor, but based on the way you look at the plan, what does it look like for '11?

I would expect 2011 will be a headwind. Again, it's so much – as you point out, so much a function of your discount rate and your return on plan asset assumptions, so there are always swings there. But using our middle-of-the-road existing rates and our assumed planned rate of return of about 9% on plan assets, you can assume about another $200 million of pension expense in 2011 increase compared to 2010.

Now 2012, the expectation is that will probably turn. In other words, it will probably go from headwind to a slight tailwind. And again depending upon assumptions, then you basically get into potential significant ramp down of those numbers.
So that comment on '11 assumes flat discount rate?
Yes.
Okay because a 1% move would make up that 200 million.
Yes, there you go. That's a good way to look at it.

The other point I guess we're forced to make though again, Shannon, is just a reminder that while the economics, if you look at our economics versus peers, cash funding needs, level of underfunding, that sort of thing, it's about the same versus all our peers. Our accounting is vastly different. It's all non-cash, but again we have a much more aggressive recognition of these non-cash loss.

Yes, I've got you. You're preaching to the choir on that one; just one last one. Dave Anderson, you mentioned that the real sequential improvement that you guys have shown in margin through the year, when you then look at the exit rates you have in some of these businesses versus what you're guiding to for 2010, ACS you're guiding next year at 12.2 to 12.6. SM is like 14.2 – 14.8, I mean far below 4Q run rates and really pretty modest even when you look at the annualized '09 numbers. Can you remind us of some of your thinking?

I think clearly we saw in ACS a very strong finish to the year. And in the calls, we talked about it – their actions that ACS took in 2009, cost actions they took, and other actions really drove that very, very strong performance.

Now for 2010, the guidance we've given you is 12.2 to 12.6; 12.2 to 12.6%. Our expectation is that ACS is going to be able to perform at the higher end of that range. So hopefully what we'll see is that kind of strength of performance. They're going to continue to benefit from good performance on the cost side. Also as we mentioned, they're seeing improvement in some of their short-cycle business, the industrial businesses, for example in ACS. On the other hand, they're going to have headwind on non-res, some non-res construction exposure and also probably on the Process Solutions side. So I think it's not unreasonable to think about ACS as being able to drive to the high end of that 2010 guidance that we've given you.
And then SM too, I mean UOP is supposed to be up next year. You've got a 17% exit rate. What's the variability factor in that?

A lot of variability is, as we've talked about and as you know, Shannon, with UOP, we saw an improvement in paraffin catalyst shipments in the fourth quarter, as we mentioned. We're expecting overall mix to influence and we've communicated that to you. The mix between license, equipment sales, and catalyst sales for UOP is always a big influence in terms of their margin rate. So we've assumed some unfavorable mix influence in terms of margins for UOP in 2010, and that flows through and influences our guidance that we've given you for total SM.
Okay, thanks a lot, guys.
And we have time for one more question.
Our final question then comes from Jeff Sprague of Citi.
Thank you, good morning.
Hi, Jeff.

Hi, everybody. Just I had a couple business questions I think we macroed top-down stuff up pretty well. Just a little bit more on ACS, I mean going back in my model even back to old Honeywell days 20 years ago, I've never seen a 14.7 margin in ACS. Dave, in your opening pitch you gave a little bit of color, but I'm just wondering if you could elaborate a little bit more about what was going on with mix or price or restructuring realization in that quarter to drive that kind of number. And I guess a little bit to Shannon's point, then why don't we get some – obviously we get a seasonal drop as we progress into 2010. But why can't we carry some of that strength over?

I'd start with all the things that you mentioned are contributing to that, and you saw them progressively getting better during the course of the year. But they've been steadily working on everything over the last five, six years. And everything is getting better, whether it's their cost position, the positioning of their products, the growth in emerging markets, all of it really is coming together to generate that kind of performance.

When we look at next year, I should say 2010 as Dave pointed out, we're looking for this to be more towards the higher end of the range as we think they're doing just a heck of a job. They'll continue to invest. They still have to roll out – finish their ERP rollout. But overall, everything is working there. Dave, anything you want to add?

I'd just say, Jeff, for 2010, consistent with what we did in the overall Honeywell walk that ACS will experience some of what we call policy related labor headwinds. Those are actions that we took in '09 that will not repeat. It certainly won't repeat in full in 2010. We've assumed that for our planning guidance. So that's going to be a headwind for ACS, but we expect that to be offset by benefits from prior period repositioning actions and other productivity. So basically, consistent with our guidance, we would see that resulting in 2010 full-year margins to be at the high end of that guidance range; so if you will again, as Dave said, flat with 2009.

And perhaps a little more minor point, but just curious on how to think about Transportation and Power. The year-over-year margins were great. Sequentially, you had a pretty nice revenue increase, almost $100 million, but margins didn't really improve sequentially.
Right.
Anything to glean from that or what that means as we go into next year – or go into 2010 I mean?

I think for TS, as we talked that, you've got a really nice tailwind on the Turbo business, driven not by the dynamics really of the European light vehicle market because we expect basically stable conditions in 2010 there, in other words not growth. So there isn't a market driven headwind. There may be some positives associated with more favorable diesel penetration. The real story is around our new product launches, Jeff, as you know, really driving that top line. And in terms of margin rate and conversion, we would expect very nice performance improvement out of TS for 2010.
And we've done a good job on their fixed costs.
We've done an excellent job on fixed costs.

So if I'm interpreting that, so there is maybe some initial launch cost, but as there's some maturation in those programs and platforms, the margins come up in those business separate and apart from just normal leverage that you'd have on revenues?

There are always the new applications that you have to spend it on. But I'd say really a simpler case is they've done a good job taking out fixed costs, and we're trying to be thoughtful on the volume side because who knows exactly what's going to happen there, but we think that the leverage in that business could be pretty darn good.

And then finally just a clarification question. Dave Anderson, did you say your biz-jet OE volumes have already seen their low, you've already felt the full production downdraft? Obviously you've got a couple more tough quarters, but you're at your trough run rate now?
Yes.
Great, thank you very much.
You're welcome.
All right; Dave, any final comments?

Yes, thanks. If I go back to the beginning, when we first got here seven, eight years ago, we said at that time that we would be a strong performer and that we would demonstrate it in cash and earnings growth. And as many of you may recall, there were a lot of question marks at the time about whether we'd be able to do that. We delivered, and as we started to get to the end of that recovery, I think we had a lot of believers that we were a different company now and a performer.

Well, as the recession started to take hold or people started talking about it, those questions rose again but in a different way, along the lines of geez, you crashed last time and lost money two years in a row. How can we believe that that's not going to happen again? I think we were able to again prove decisively that we were not that same company. So in a totally different environment, bad times, we were able to demonstrate that we were not that same company. When you look at the last recession in the year 2000, we actually had about a 75% free cash flow conversion. In this recession, we've got free cash flow conversion of around 150%, hugely different.

Now we're embarking or at the beginning of likely another recovery. And what we're going to say is we think that we have prepared well for it for all the same reasons that we were prepared for the recession. The reasons haven't changed. It's seed planting to having great positions in good industries, the One Honeywell, focus, our five initiatives, our strong acquisitions process. All those things that helped us in the previous good times, that helped us in the decline, are also going to help us in the recovery.

So I guess it's a long way of saying I think we're a company you should bet on. And when it comes to is there a company that you can trust out there, I think Honeywell is a pretty good bet for you. Thanks.
Thank you for your participation today and I'll be available all day for your questions.
And that does conclude today's conference, ladies and gentlemen. Again we appreciate everyone's participation today.
